awd_titl_txt: The Boulder Space Weather Summer School
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support activities to organize and hold an annual Boulder Space Weather Summer School. The summer school will bring up to thirty students to Boulder, Colorado for two weeks and immerse them in class room teaching covering fundamental science of the Sun-Earth system and the socioeconomic impacts of space weather, with a particular emphasis on modeling and forecasting. Space weather events can adversely impact our nation's economy and national security by degrading satellite-based services such as high frequency (HF) communication, global positioning system (GPS) position and navigation. To monitor space weather, a new generation of workforce is needed that is highly trained in the fundamental physics of the geospace environment and is equally adept at using various numerical models and observational tools. The summer school will train a new generation of solar and space scientists, space weather forecasters, and engineers and operators of system that are impacted by space weather events. 

This activity will organize the Boulder Space Weather Summer school for three years to train a new generation of solar and space scientists, forecasters, and engineers. The school will enable students to interact with expert lecturers and engage them in interactive learning activities that are designed to promote both conceptual understanding and practical skills relevant to space weather. The school will also develop improved metrics and assessment procedures to better evaluate the School's impact and to better track and promote diversity. The proposed activity also includes outreach activities to engage more students from under-represented demographics in space weather research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Space weather, the dynamic conditions in space driven by solar activity, poses significant challenges to modern technology and infrastructure on Earth. Recognizing the importance of understanding and mitigating these effects, a collaborative project was undertaken to enhance space weather education and training. Through the Boulder Space Weather Summer School (BSWSS) and strategic partnerships with organizations like the Space Weather Prediction Center (SWPC), the project aimed to empower the next generation of space weather scientists and practitioners.

A key outcome of the project has been the training of 96 students over the course of three BSWSS sessions held in 2018, 2019, and 2022. These intensive two-week programs provided graduate and undergraduate students with a comprehensive understanding of space weather fundamentals, computational modeling techniques, and the practical implications of space weather phenomena. By offering formal lectures, hands-on lab activities, and interactions with leading experts, the BSWSS has equipped participants with the knowledge and skills necessary to address complex challenges in the field.

The project has forged collaborative partnerships with organizations such as the SWPC, leveraging their expertise and resources to enrich the educational experience of participants. Professional staff from the SWPC served as guest lecturers during the BSWSS, offering insights into operational forecasting techniques and the real-world impacts of space weather events. Additionally, tours of SWPC facilities provided participants with firsthand exposure to the operational aspects of space weather monitoring and forecasting, enhancing their understanding of the field.

A notable outcome of the project has been the implementation of innovative teaching methodologies and technologies to enhance space weather education. Core lab capabilities were transitioned to a cloud-based platform, allowing students to access computational resources and interact with 3D models of space weather phenomena.

The project has had a significant impact on the development of the space weather discipline by fostering the growth of human resources and expertise in the field. By providing participants with a broad understanding of key components of space weather science, the project has empowered them to pursue careers as skilled researchers, forecasters, and educators. Furthermore, collaborations with organizations like the SWPC have facilitated connections between academia and operational forecasting, strengthening the interdisciplinary nature of space weather research and applications.

 

Conclusion:

In conclusion, the collaborative project aimed at advancing space weather education has yielded significant outcomes that benefit both the scientific community and society at large. By training the next generation of space weather scientists, forging collaborative partnerships, and implementing innovative teaching methodologies, the project has contributed to the development of a skilled workforce capable of addressing the challenges posed by space weather. Moving forward, continued efforts to enhance space weather education and training will be essential to ensure the resilience and sustainability of our technological infrastructure in the face of space weather threats.
